etymologies: late Middle English (in an earlier sense). From Anglo-Norman pel, peel, peau, etc., and Middle French pel, peau, etc. (French peau) animal skin or hide, human skin, parchment from classical Latin pellis skin, leather, parchment from the same Indo-European base as fell

definitions: A parchment; specifically either of two rolls of parchment for recording receipts (called in Latin the pellis receptorum) and issues (called in Latin the pellis exituum), formerly kept at the Exchequer.
With the and capital initial. The Office of the Exchequer in which these rolls were kept.

etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Joseph Strutt (1749–1802), antiquary and engraver. From Anglo-Norman and Old French, Middle French pel peel; for the specific sense compare pale

definitions: A stake or post at which to practise sword-strokes.
